posts.name: Venu Vardhan Reddy Tekula
posts.cooked:
I see the right swipe action on a conversation will archive it.

1080×532 33 KB

How about delete instead of archive?
or maybe right swipe - archive, left swipe - delete or vice-versa

AFAIK, Gmail has such a setting.

It is easy to delete many spam SMS using swipe actions to keep the inbox clean.

Got this idea suggestion, so thought of sharing it here to read more views on this.
Thanks.

link_counts.title: Swipe to archive is too easy to trigger accidentally
Swipe to navigate between chat folders
Option to disable "swipe to leave chat"

notice.raw: This feature request was originally only about adding a delete swipe action, but it has been combined with several other feature requests to be a general "customizable swipe action" request, as not everyone wants the same set of swipe actions (or any swipe actions at all).
notice.cooked: This feature request was originally only about adding a delete swipe action, but it has been combined with several other feature requests to be a general “customizable swipe action” request, as not everyone wants the same set of swipe actions (or any swipe actions at all).

posts.cooked:
Seems like this feature is there in iOS and so for parity it makes sense to have it in Android too. Only question is what happens with accidental swiping. Maybe delaying permanent deletion would be good enough.

Swipe to delete Message Sensitivity iOS Support
On Signal 3.18, I have noticed when I come to swipe left to delete a conversation, the action is sensitive, and instead of deleting sometimes it archives the message instead. Only started happening on 3.18, if I swipe left quickly to delete it archives the message instead of deleting the message

posts.name: Venu Vardhan Reddy Tekula
posts.cooked:
Seems like this feature is there in iOS and so for parity it makes sense to have it in Android too.

I didn’t see this feature in Android.
Thanks for letting me know about it.

Only question is what happens with accidental swiping. Maybe delaying permanent deletion would be good enough.

I see there is a popup/notification below, to undo the swiping action whenever I trigger it. Maybe delete should have something similar.

IMG_20210110_1858321080×396 33.5 KB

newuser:

Only question is what happens with accidental swiping.

This would definitely be a problem; I’ve accidentally swipe-archived conversations a lot of times. Luckily that has an undo toast so you can fix it if you’re fast enough before it goes away. Deletion is a bit more tricky to undo compared to archiving, but it would need something like that if they were to implement it.

They could also add a confirmation dialog, which Gmail has, though it also gives you the option to disable it.
Confirmation dialog would be great and they probably wouldn’t be against the idea since they added a confirmation dialog for calls.

Confirmation dialog or a 5min window for undoing delete? The latter is more convenient especially for SMS. Only issue is what if someone wants to swipe delete to protect themselves quickly from when someone else is going to get access to their device?

posts.name: Retik Singh
posts.cooked: If both options are present that would be great. Like one or the other thing.

newuser:

quickly from when someone else is going to get access to their device?

In this case the signal screen lock would probably be a better option (just press the lock now putton)

Tursko:

they probably wouldn’t be against the idea since they added a confirmation dialog for calls

There allready is a confirmation dialogue for deleting a chat
The only thing missing is the swipe gesture to activate it

newuser:

Confirmation dialog or a 5min window for undoing delete?

Why not both?

In a desktop you have the recycle bin for when you hit delete and it can be bypassed if you hit shift+delete. Confirmation dialogs can be disabled for any/both actions. Maybe swipe can simulate delete and long press+tap trashcan icon can simulate shift+delete.

Retik_Singh:

If both options are present that would be great

github.com

signalapp/Signal-Android/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-ideology

# Contributing to Signal Android

Thank you for supporting Signal and looking for ways to help. Please note that some conventions here might be a bit different than what you are used to, even if you have contributed to other open source projects before. Reading this document will help you save time and work effectively with the developers and other contributors.


## Development Ideology

Truths which we believe to be self-evident:

1. **The answer is not more options.**  If you feel compelled to add a preference that's exposed to the user, it's very possible you've made a wrong turn somewhere.
1. **The user doesn't know what a key is.**  We need to minimize the points at which a user is exposed to this sort of terminology as extremely as possible.
1. **There are no power users.**  The idea that some users "understand" concepts better than others has proven to be, for the most part, false. If anything, "power users" are more dangerous than the rest, and we should avoid exposing dangerous functionality to them.
1. **If it's "like PGP," it's wrong.**  PGP is our guide for what not to do.
1. **It's an asynchronous world.**  Be wary of anything that is anti-asynchronous: ACKs, protocol confirmations, or any protocol-level "advisory" message.
1. **There is no such thing as time.**  Protocol ideas that require synchronized clocks are doomed to failure.


## Building

1. You'll need to get the `libwebp` submodule after checking out the repository with `git submodule init && git submodule update`
This file has been truncated. show original

posts.name: ch4tterb0x
posts.cooked:
What do u think about unifying the behaviour of swipes on chats in iOS and Android?

Currently on iOS it’s:
| Unread | Pin | Chat —> (swipe to the right)

ios-swipe-right1124×210 15 KB

<— Chat | Delete | Archive | (swipe to left)

ios-swipe-left1124×210 9.81 KB

A ‘small’ swipe shows both options and a ‘large’ swipe activates the most outer options (Unread or Archive)

More Examples

Long swipe right:

ios-swipe-righ-long1124×216 13.1 KB

Long swipe left:

ios-swipe-left-large1124×213 5.84 KB

Delete cannot be activaed on accident and as mentioned before, pressing it will promt to confirm it.
I think this works quite well and gives easy and fast access to the four features.

I think this would work great on both platforms iOS and Android. But to be honest i don’t know if this would be against the interface design normally used on Android or against the design ideas behind signal on Android.

I don’t like the usage of these swipe actions since in every app they are used differently, and also there is a difference between swiping from the screen edge and swiping on an UI element.

The problem is, as Herohtar wrote, accidental usage. Firstly the user can’t know for sure what the swipe action will do before initiating it (since there is nothing visual before beginning the action). And secondly as e.g. Telegram uses swipe to open a menu, and Signal doesnt’t, I will always make mistakes on both applications.

Accidentally archieving is a nuisance which I have often done but it can be undone. I don’t like the idea that I may accidentally delete a chat and then also miss the “undo” toast after which everything is lost.

How often do you anyways delete a chat? Or archieve it? Those actions which are not often used, should be in places which are harder to activate accidentally. Marking as unread would be an example of a harmless action which is quite often used, why not use it as the swipe action.

posts.name: ch4tterb0x
posts.cooked:
ElektroVirus:

I don’t like the idea that I may accidentally delete a chat and then also miss the “undo” toast after which everything is lost.

This could be mittigated by just keeping the current behaviour when deletening chats. If you delete a chat (no matter where u initiate it) you get a promt asking to verify you realy want to delete this chat.
In my opinion there is no nead for undoing deletions with this behaviour. But it wouldn’t hurt to have either.

ElektroVirus:

The problem is, as Herohtar wrote, accidental usage.

I don’t think this is a problem, since the user sees, while swiping, what compleating the swipte would do. Furthermore the actions are just comleated if you swipe long on purpose. A short swipe only opens the ‘menu’ and shows you the possible options.

ElektroVirus:

And secondly as e.g. Telegram uses swipe to open a menu, and Signal doesnt’t, I will always make mistakes on both applications.

At least on iOS the outer most options, that can be choosen by swiping longer after you opened the menu, are the same across almost all messangers i know.
In addition if ‘Delete’ is one of the outer most options it can only be choosen by pressing it after swiping.

More details on the 'swipe menus' of other Messangers

Unfortunately i don’t know how those messangers act on Android but i assume they do the same, since as far as i know this messangers have a pretty consistent UX across iOS and Android.

Whatsapp
| Un/read | Pin | Chat → (swipe right)
Long swipe right is like pressing ‘Un/read’
← Chat | More | Archive | (swipe left)
Long swipe left is like pressing ‘Archive’

Telegram
| Un/read | Pin | Chat → (swipe right)
Long swipe right is like pressing ‘Un/read’
← Chat | Mute | Delete | Archiv | (swipe left)
Long swipe left is like pressing ‘Archive’
(The only difference for telegram is, all swipe guestures must start at the edge of the screen since normal swiping is used to switch between different ‘chat collections’.

iMessage
| Pin | Chat → (swipe right)
Long swipe right is like pressing ‘Pin’
← Chat | Mute | Delete (swipe left)
Long swipe left does nothing. (Prevents accidential deleting)

Threema
| Pin | Chat → (swipe right)
Long swipe right is like pressing ‘Pin’
← Chat | Delete (swipe left)
Long swipe left does nothing. (Prevents accidential deleting)

Signal (on iOS)
| un/read | pin | Chat → (swipe right)
Long swipe right is like pressing ‘un/read’
← Chat | delete | archive | (swipe left)
Long swipe left is like pressing ‘archive’

I don’t see any problems for signal4android in adopting the behaviour of signal4ios. Those menus seem like they are pretty common across all messangers and seem to act in a similar way across all messangers. The only exception seems to be signal4android, which like ElektroVirus said might leed to confusion.

In all of this menues it is not possible to accidentially delete a chate since you have to presse the delete entries after revealing them with a swipe. (You cannot delete only by swiping)
Those ‘swipe menus’ bring easy acces to functionality commonly used with chats. (un/read, pin, mute, delete, archive, …)
While giving easy access they prevent the user from accidently doing harm. By not allowing harming actions to be completed only by swiping, without giving an option to undo it.

Signal sometimes does stuff different because of privacy. This does not apply here.

I do understand signal sometime has its own approaches to how some featrues work, due to the focus on privacy. But i do not see how a different approach on this can enhance the privacy of the user.
This is also shown by the fact signal4ios already uses this standard of ‘swipe menus’.

Just curious are those ‘swipe menus’ not common in messangers on Android. Is this just a thing on iOS?

chatterbox:

Just curious are those ‘swipe menus’ not common in messangers on Android. Is this just a thing on iOS?

Threema uses two Swipe Actions: Pin & Archive. Both ar non-destructive actions.
And I would argue that we don’t need this kind of ‘quick setting’ for Delete, Notifications etc - because honestly, how often are those used?

posts.name: ch4tterb0x
posts.cooked:
MrShadowfly:

Threema uses two Swipe Actions: Pin & Archive. Both ar non-destructive actions.

Are they purly swiping actions?
(The options cannot be used with a swiping guestour cannot be activated by tapping on them)

Or does swiping act like opening a menu?
(The actions can stay on the screen without beeing activated and can be activated by pressing it.)

In the first case i agree there should only be the most two usefull and nondestructive actions.

In the second case, when it acts like a menu, i don’t see how having more options can do any harm.
You can still access the nondistructive functions by swiping and harming actions need to be ‘confirmed’ by pressing the option.
(Deleting a chat then still promts you to confirm you want to delete it.)

I don’t see any reason there should not be more options then just archive. For examoel there can be cases when you quickly need or want to delete a chat. “Swipe once, press delete, confirm the promt, done.”

You don’t loose functionality but you gain new, without introducing major new issues, like accidently deleting a chat by swiping.

chatterbox:

Are they purly swiping actions?

Yes, no menu thingy. And I’ve never seen something like that on Android before, so it might not be that typical. On Android, most actions, especially not much used ones, have to be placed in the three dots-menu on the top right. That is where people expect it.

MrShadowfly:

Yes, no menu thingy. And I’ve never seen something like that on Android before, so it might not be that typical.

The only place that I recall seeing any behavior like this on Android is in the notifications – you can swipe a notification slightly to the side to reveal a settings button. I don’t know of any apps that do that. Typically there is just a swipe action.

Yeah, you’re right.

I would also add that - as far as I can see - material design does not intend to have this kind of ‘swipe to reveal menu’ behaviour. See Lists – Material Design 3
